questions.text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder?
questions.solution:
The most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder is the Phrygian cap. It refers to an inward folding of the fundus of the gallbladder. It is named for its resemblance to a conical hat.

The other common congenital anomalies of the gallbladder are:

  • Agenesis - absence of all or any portion of the hepatic or common bile ducts
  • Biliary atresia - hypoplastic narrowing of biliary channels
  • Choledochal cysts - congenital dilations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary system

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with severe right upper quadrant pain for 8 hours associated with nausea and vomiting. A diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made and he underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The specimen is shown below. This finding is associated with all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gallstones, which are not associated with hyperlipidemia syndromes.

Pigmented gallstones are made of bilirubin and calcium salts. They can occur in:

  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Ileal resection
  • Biliary infection
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol stones are made of crystalline cholesterol monohydrates. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was rushed to the ER with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 hours. He had been diagnosed with gallstones 10 years ago but had not undergone any treatment. Imaging revealed gallbladder wall thickening. He underwent a cholecystectomy which revealed a shrunken and nodular gallbladder with a thick wall. The following was noted on microscopy. This condition is associated with:

choices.text: Dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of chronic cholecystitis and image showing lipid-laden xanthoma cells are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis. This condition results due to the rupture of Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses.

Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are bile-filled outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall. They develop in reaction to chronic inflammation of the gallbladder. Eventually, they may rupture into the wall of the gallbladder. This results in the accumulation of macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids, which are called xanthoma cells.

Chronic cholecystitis may have other sequelae:

  • Porcelain gallbladder - dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall
  • Hyalinizing cholecystitis - replacement of the gallbladder wall by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification (leads to higher incidence of gallbladder carcinoma)
  • Hydrops of the gallbladder - atrophic, obstructed, dilated gallbladder containing clear fluid

Acute cholecystitis includes the following variants:

  • Emphysematous cholecystitis - acute infection of the gallbladder by gas-forming organisms
  • Acalculous cholecystitis - due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia

questions.text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.

The pancreas develops by fusion of the larger dorsal and smaller ventral pancreatic buds. The dorsal duct is the dominant duct during development and it drains into the minor papilla. The ventral duct drains into the major papilla. After fusion, the following ducts are formed: 

  • Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) - formed by fusion of ducts of dorsal and ventral buds, drains into the major papilla
  • Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) - formed by the proximal portion of the dorsal duct, drains into the minor papilla

In pancreas divisum, the ventral and dorsal ducts fail to fuse. Hence, the majority of the pancreas continues to drain through the dominant dorsal duct that enters the duodenum at the minor papilla while the ventral duct, along with the bile duct, drains into the major papilla. These patients are more prone to pancreatitis.

The other congenital anomalies of the pancreas are:

  • Annular pancreas - band-like ring of normal pancreatic tissue encircling 2nd part of duodenum, may cause obstruction
  • Ectopic pancreas - common in stomach, duodenum, and jejunum (found in about 2% of postmortem exams)
  • Agenesis - rarely seen, associated with mutations of PDX1 (homeobox gene)

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with severe abdominal pain for the last 24 hours with radiation to the upper back. He has had multiple similar episodes since his childhood. Family history revealed similar episodes in the father. Investigations revealed elevated serum levels of amylase and lipase. Which of the following statements is not true about the given condition?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with mutations in the PRSS1 gene
This boy has a 40 % lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer
It may be associated with mutations in the CFTR gene
Hypocalcemia is an important triggering factor this condition

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in a young patient with positive family history of similar episodes is suggestive of hereditary pancreatitis. Acute episodes of pancreatitis can be precipitated by hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.

The following genes are implicated in hereditary pancreatitis:

  • Gain-of-function mutation in trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) - most common 
  • Loss-of-function mutation in trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)
  • Loss of CFTR - abnormal secretions that promote protein plugging, duct obstruction, leading to pancreatitis 

Hereditary pancreatitis is associated with a 40% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer.

  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with vague abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss for the last 6 months. He also reported spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly arranged nodules at different locations on his body. On examination, thrombophlebitis and epigastric tenderness were noted. Investigations revealed elevated serum CEA and CA 19-9. Which of the following genetic mutations is most frequently associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of the above clinical symptoms with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. The most frequently associated mutation with this condition is K-RAS.

It is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumor or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.

Molecular alterations involved in pancreatic carcinogenesis are:

Gene Type  Chromosome
KRAS (most common oncogene) Oncogene (activated by point mutation) 12p
CDKN2A (most common tumor-suppressor gene) Tumor suppressor gene 9p
TP53 Tumor suppressor gene 17p
SMAD4 Tumor suppressor gene 18q

 

Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:

  • BRCA2 mutation - pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers
  • PRSS1 mutation - pancreatic carcinoma secondary to hereditary pancreatitis

questions.text: A pathologist was studying a biopsy specimen from a patient with pancreatic cancer. He observed that it resembled ovarian stroma. What is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
Mucinous cystic neoplasms of the pancreas have dense stroma, similar to the ovarian stroma.

These tumors have large cystic cavities filled with thick, tenacious mucin. They are lined by columnar, mucin-producing epithelium with dense stroma. This results in similarity to ovarian stroma.

They usually arise in the tail of the pancreas and can be precursors to invasive carcinomas. They are associated with mutations in the KRAS oncogene, and the tumor-suppressor genes TP53 and RNF43.

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except:

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.solution:
Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas develop jaundice due to obstruction of the biliary tract.

Cigarette smoking doubles the risk of pancreatic cancer and is the leading preventable cause. The clinical features depend on the location of the tumor.

  • Head - painless, palpable gallbladder with mild jaundice is suggestive of malignancy (according to Courvoisier's law) 
  • Body and tail - may remain asymptomatic until later stages as they do not impinge on the biliary tract and do not cause jaundice

Other common pathological features of this condition are:

  • Desmoplastic reaction - growth of fibrous or connective tissue
  • Perineural invasion, as well as lymphatic and large vessel invasion

questions.text: Patients with which of the following have the highest risk of pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Patients with Peutz–Jeghers syndrome have the highest risk of pancreatic cancer.
